THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Tawanda Simpson, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        World Finance Corporation of South Carolina and World Acceptance Corporation, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Laurens County
Â James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4059
Heard November 9, 2005 â€“ Filed December 12, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Judson K. Chapin, III, of Greenville; for Appellants.
        Matthew Price Turner, of Laurens; Rhett D. Burney, of Laurens; for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  World Finance Corporation of South Carolina and World Acceptance Corporation (â€œAppellantsâ€) appeal the circuit courtâ€™s order denying their motion to compel arbitration.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Beginning in March 2001 through July 2002, Tawanda Simpson entered into a series of consumer loan transactions with Appellants.Â  In conjunction with each of these loan agreements, Simpson signed an arbitration agreement, which provided that the parties agreed to settle all disputes and claims through arbitration.Â  
In late 2002, after Simpson had paid her loan in full, former employees of Appellants used Simpsonâ€™s personal financial information to illegally procure loans and embezzle the proceeds from those loans.[1]Â  Upon discovering the misuse of her personal information, Simpson filed suit against Appellants seeking a jury trial for damages arising out of the following causes of action:Â  intentional infliction of emotional distress; negligence; negligent hiring/supervision; and unfair trade practices.Â  In response, Appellants denied the allegations and filed a motion to dismiss pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, and a motion to compel arbitration. 
After a hearing, the circuit court denied Appellantsâ€™ motions to dismiss and to compel arbitration.Â  In reaching this decision, the court found the creditor/debtor relationship between Appellants and Simpson ended once Simpson satisfied her loan in full.Â  As a result, the court concluded the â€œeffectiveness of the arbitration clause ceased when the relationship of the parties ceased.â€Â  The court also held the tort claims raised by Simpson were not subject to arbitration because the acts of Appellantsâ€™ employees were â€œcompletely independent of the loan agreement.â€Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe question whether a claim is subject to arbitration is a matter of judicial determination, unless the parties have provided otherwise.Â  Appeal from the denial of a motion to compel arbitration is subject to de novo review.â€Â  Chassereau v. Global-Sun Pools, Inc., 363 S.C. 628, 631, 611 S.E.2d 305, 307 (Ct. App. 2005) (citations omitted).
DISCUSSION
Appellants argue the circuit court erred in denying their motion to compel arbitration.[2]Â  Specifically, they contend that once the court determined that an arbitration agreement existed between the parties, the courtâ€™s â€œdecisional functionâ€ was completed and any decisions regarding the validity of the agreement and the arbitrability of Simpsonâ€™s claims were to be decided by an arbitrator.Â  Even if the circuit court was authorized to determine the effectiveness of the agreement, Appellants claim the broad terms of the arbitration agreement encompassed any disputes beyond the expiration of the underlying loan transactions between the parties.Â  
 As a threshold matter, we find Appellantsâ€™ argument that the circuit courtâ€™s authority was strictly limited to determining whether the parties entered into an arbitration agreement is not properly before this court.Â  First, Appellants did not raise this precise argument in their motion to compel arbitration or during the hearing before the circuit court.Â  Secondly, the circuit court did not address this issue in its order, but instead, only ruled on the effectiveness of the arbitration agreement.Â  Appellants did not file a motion pursuant to Rule 59 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure to challenge this omission.Â  See Lucas v. Rawl Family Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 359 S.C. 505, 511, 598 S.E.2d 712, 715 (2004) (recognizing that in order for an issue to be preserved for appellate review, with few exceptions, it must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial court); Hawkins v. Mullins, 359 S.C. 497, 502, 597 S.E.2d 897, 899 (Ct. App. 2004) (noting an issue is not preserved where the trial court does not explicitly rule on an argument and the appellant does not make a Rule 59(e) motion to alter or amend the judgment). 
In terms of the merits of Appellantsâ€™ motion to compel arbitration, we turn to recently established precedent.Â  â€œArbitration is a matter of contract, and the range of issues that can be arbitrated is restricted by the terms of the agreement.â€Â  Palmetto Homes, Inc. v. Bradley, 357 S.C. 485, 492, 593 S.E.2d 480, 484 (Ct. App. 2004), cert. denied (July 8, 2005).Â  Our supreme court has outlined the analytical framework for determining whether a particular claim is subject to arbitration.Â  Zabinski v. Bright Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 597, 553 S.E.2d 110, 118-19 (2001).Â  In Zabinski, the court stated:

  To decide whether an arbitration agreement encompasses a dispute, a court must determine whether the factual allegations underlying the claim are within the scope of the broad arbitration clause, regardless of the label assigned to the claim. Hinson v. Jusco Co., 868 F.Supp. 145 (D.S.C. 1994); S.C. Pub. Serv. Auth. v. Great W. Coal, 312 S.C. 559, 437 S.E.2d 22 (1993).Â  Any doubts concerning the scope of arbitrable issues should be resolved in favor of arbitration. Towles, supra.Â  Furthermore, unless the court can say with positive assurance that the arbitration clause is not susceptible to an interpretation that covers the dispute, arbitration should be ordered. Great W. Coal, 312 S.C. at 564, 437 S.E.2d at 25.Â  A motion to compel arbitration made pursuant to an arbitration clause in a written contract should only be denied where the clause is not susceptible to any interpretation which would cover the asserted dispute. Â Tritech, supra.

Id. at 597, 553 S.E.2d at 118-19.Â  The court further articulated that â€œ[a] broadly-worded arbitration clause applies to disputes that do not arise under the governing contract when a â€˜significant relationshipâ€™ exists between the asserted claims and the contract in which the arbitration clause is contained.â€Â  Id. at 119, 553 S.E.2d at 598.Â  
With respect to tort claims, the supreme court noted the test from other jurisdictions stating, â€œthe focus should be on the factual allegations contained in the petition rather than on the legal causes of actions asserted.â€Â  Zabinski, 346 S.C. at 597 n.4, 553 S.E.2d at 119 n.4.Â  The court elaborated:

  The test is based on a determination of whether the particular tort claim is so interwoven with the contract that it could not stand alone.Â  If the tort and contract claims are so interwoven, both are arbitrable.Â  On the other hand, if the tort claim is completely independent of the contract and could be maintained without reference to the contract, the tort claim is not arbitrable. 

Id.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Shortly after the supreme court issued its decision in Zabinski, this court had the opportunity to apply the principles set forth and to interpret the â€œsignificant relationshipâ€ test.Â  Vestry & Church Wardens of the Church of the Holy Cross v. Orkin Exterminating Co., 356 S.C. 202, 588 S.E.2d 136 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Although this court utilized the Zabinski principles to analyze the question of whether separate arbitration agreements previously executed by the parties mandated arbitration for the claims in dispute, we believe the holding is, nevertheless, instructive.Â  In Vestry, we concluded, â€œthe mere fact that an arbitration clause might apply to matters beyond the express scope of the underlying contract does not alone imply that the clause should apply to every dispute between the parties.â€Â  Id. at 209, 588 S.E.2d at 140.Â  
The arbitration agreement in the instant case provides in relevant part:

  ALL DISPUTES, CONTROVERSIES OR CLAIMS OF ANY KIND AND NATURE BETWEEN LENDER AND BORROWER ARISING OUT OF OR IN CONNECTION WITH THE LOAN AGREEMENT, OR ARISING OUT OF ANY TRANSACTION OR RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN LENDER AND BORROWER OR ARISING OUT OF ANY PRIOR OR FUTURE DEALINGS BETWEEN LENDER AND BORROWER, SHALL BE SUBMITTED TO ARBITRATION AND SETTLED BY ARBITRATION IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE UNITED STATES ARBITRATION ACT, THE EXPEDITED PROCEDURES OF THE COMMERCIAL ARBITRATION RULES OF THE AMERICAN ARBITRATION ASSOCIATION (THE â€œARBITRATION RULES OF THE AAAâ€), AND THIS AGREEMENT. 

(Emphasis added).Â  We would also note the arbitration agreement contained a provision that stated, â€œThis Agreement applies even if the Loan Agreement is paid in full, charged-off by Lender, or discharged in Bankruptcy.â€ 
Given the broadly worded terms of the arbitration agreement, it is plausible that one could initially conclude that Simpsonâ€™s claims were subject to arbitration.Â  However, as discussed above, the terms alone are not dispositive of this determination.Â  Instead, we are required to focus on the factual allegations of the underlying causes of action to analyze whether a â€œsignificant relationshipâ€ existed between the claims and the loan contract.Â Â Â  Moreover, because Simpson had satisfied her loan in full at the time her claims arose, we must also look at the partiesâ€™ intent to assess whether the arbitration agreement extended beyond the termination of the contract.Â  See Towles v. United Healthcare Corp., 338 S.C. 29, 41, 524 S.E.2d 839, 846 (Ct. App. 1999)(â€œWhen a party invokes an arbitration clause after the contractual relationship between the parties has ended, the partiesâ€™ intent governs whether the clauseâ€™s authority extends beyond the termination of the contract.â€); see Zabinski, 346 S.C. at 596, 553 S.E.2d at 118 (â€œArbitration is a matter of contract, and a party cannot be required to submit to arbitration any dispute which he has not agreed to submit.â€).Â  
Applying the foregoing principles to the specific facts of this case, we agree with the circuit courtâ€™s conclusion that Simpsonâ€™s claims were not subject to arbitration. Â Initially, we reject Appellantsâ€™ contention that the claims arose out of the loan agreement simply because Appellantsâ€™ employees would not have had access to Simpsonâ€™s personal financial information but for the loan agreement.Â  Although Appellantsâ€™ assertion is factually accurate, it disregards the analytical framework for determining whether claims are arbitrable.Â  Simpsonâ€™s tort claims are independent of the loan agreement and require no reference to the contract.Â  At the time Appellantsâ€™ employees misused Simpsonâ€™s personal financial information, Simpson had paid off her loan in full.Â  Thus, a â€œsignificant relationshipâ€ does not exist between Simpsonâ€™s claims and the loan agreement.Â  Moreover, it is inconceivable that Simpson intended to agree to maintain a contractual relationship with Appellants in perpetuity after she paid off her loan.Â  Given Simpson had satisfied her contractual obligation, no further dealings with Appellants were necessary.Â  Finally, we do not believe she could have foreseen the future tortious conduct of Appellantsâ€™ employees at the time she entered into the loan agreements.Â  
Additionally, we believe our holding is consistent with this courtâ€™s recent decision in Chassereau v. Global-Sun Pools, Inc., 363 S.C. 628, 611 S.E.2d 305 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  In Chassereau, a homeowner entered into a contract for the construction of a pool by Global-Sun Pools.Â  The contract contained an arbitration provision that applied to â€œany disputes arising in any manner relating to this agreement.â€Â  Id. at 633, 611 S.E.2d at 307.Â Â  After construction was completed, the homeowner began to experience problems with the pool.Â  Because Global-Sun Pools failed to repair the pool, the homeowner stopped making payments on the pool.Â  Id. at 630, 611 S.E.2d at 306.Â  A few months later, the homeowner filed a complaint against the pool company and one of its employees, alleging this employee and other employees made a series of harassing and intimidating telephone calls to her workplace.Â  The homeowner claimed the pool companyâ€™s employees made defamatory statements about her to her co-workers and they disclosed information regarding her personal finances.Â  Additionally, the homeowner asserted these same employees made numerous telephone calls to her home as well as to her relatives in an effort to intimidate and harass her.Â  Id.Â Â  
In her complaint, the homeowner sought damages based on causes of action for defamation, violation of South Carolina Code of Laws section 16-17-430 which prohibits unlawful use of a telephone, and intentional infliction of emotional distress.Â  Id. at 631, 611 S.E.2d at 306.Â  The pool company and its employee filed a motion to compel arbitration, alleging the provisions of the construction contract mandated arbitration.Â  The circuit court denied the motion, finding â€œ[t]he complaint is based upon tortious conduct of the employees of [Global-Sun Pools] unrelated to the contractâ€ and the â€œallegations of the complaint do not arise out of nor do they relate to the contract[.]â€Â  Id. at 631, 611 S.E.2d at 306-07.
On appeal, this court affirmed the circuit courtâ€™s decision.Â  In so holding, we found the homeownerâ€™s claims did not arise out of the construction contract and could be proved independently of the contract.Â  We further concluded the causes of action alleged in the complaint â€œconstitute[d] tortious behavior that the parties . . . could not have reasonably foreseen and for which we seriously doubt they intended to provide a limited means of redress.â€Â  Id. at 634, 611 S.E.2d at 308.
Similar to the homeownerâ€™s tort claims in Chassereau, Simpsonâ€™s tort claims did not arise out of the loan agreement and could be proved independently of this agreement.Â  Although we are cognizant of the policy favoring arbitration, we do not believe arbitration is warranted for Simpsonâ€™s claims.Â  See Zabinski, 346 S.C. at 596, 553 S.E.2d at 118 (â€œThe policy of the United States and South Carolina is to favor arbitration of disputes.â€). 
Accordingly, the decision of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF, J., concur.

[1]Â  The former employees pleaded guilty for these offenses and were sentenced in the United States District Court for the District of South Carolina. 
[2]Â  Although Appellants raise four issues in their brief, we have consolidated these issues in the interest of brevity and clarity.

description: Concludes that a "plea" agreement between prosecution and Compton did not grant Compton immunity from prosecution and, additionally, affirms the trial court's admission of evidence about statements made by Compton.

State v. Compton


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Otis James Compton, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Abbeville County
Wyatt T. Saunders, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4060
Heard November 11, 2005 â€“ Filed December 19, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia and Ernest Charles Grose, Jr., of Greenwood, for Appellant.Â  
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Â Assistant Attorney General Jeffrey A. Jacobs, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Jerry W. Peace, of Greenwood, for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  Otis James Compton appeals his convictions for murder, burglary in the first degree, armed robbery, possession of a firearm or knife during the commission of a violent crime, and malicious injury to real property.Â  He contends an agreement granted him immunity from prosecution on the charges in exchange for his cooperation with a police investigation.Â  Additionally, he raises several evidentiary and constitutional issues.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In August 1999, Johnny Hanna was murdered in his home during an apparent burglary.Â  Compton was originally questioned about the crime that same month.Â  In November 1999, Compton pled guilty to several unrelated counts of burglary and was sentenced to a total of fifteen years imprisonment.Â  Compton remained a person of interest in the Hanna murder.Â  
In January 2000, Compton was placed in a holding cell along with Tracey Black after they each had pled guilty to charges unrelated to the Hanna murder.Â  According to Black, Compton initiated a discussion regarding the Hanna murder and told Black, â€œhe had done what he had to do.â€Â  Black informed investigators of this conversation.Â  In March 2000, Black was transferred to the same prison where Compton was housed.Â  He was told by investigators to â€œlisten to Mr. Compton and see if he would talk about the case any more or what he had done or any involvement in it.Â  They told me that I could not question the guy or pursue nothing toward him, just listen.â€Â  Black was eventually placed in a cell with Compton and relayed to police several conversations in which Compton admitted taking part in the burglary and murder of Hanna.Â  
In July 2000, Compton was in the Abbeville County Courthouse for the trial of his wife on unrelated charges.Â  While there, he sought out Sheriff Goodwin regarding the Hanna investigation.Â  Subsequently, Sheriff Goodwin, Lieutenant Templeton, Solicitor Townes Jones, and Comptonâ€™s attorney, Joe Smithdeal, met at Smithdealâ€™s office to talk about an agreement.Â  The agreement at issue was labeled â€œPlea Agreementâ€ and required Compton to â€œfully and truthfully cooperate . . . in their investigation of the events involving the death of Johnny Hanna.â€Â  In exchange, the State agreed â€œto reduce the sentences by all reasonable means on [the unrelated burglary charges] to Burglary Second Degree, Non-Violent, for Seven and One-half (7-1/2) years, to run concurrent with each other and concurrent with all other sentences now serving, within 18 months of arrest or within 2 years from the date of this agreement.â€Â  
Compton subsequently admitted he was present at the time of the murder of Hanna.Â  He told investigators that two other men took part in the crime and that he drove the getaway vehicle. Â Compton was indicted for the murder of Hanna, as well as other related charges.Â  Before trial, Compton moved to quash the indictment or suppress his statements to police on the grounds that the information was provided subject to an immunity agreement between Compton and the solicitor.Â  The motion also alleged the evidence should be suppressed because it violated Rule 410, SCRE,[1] and the investigators violated his Fifth and Sixth Amendment rights.Â  The trial court denied the motion, finding there was no reasonable expectation of immunity, the agreement was not entered into pursuant to plea negotiations, and Compton breached the agreement by failing to pass the polygraph test.Â  
Compton was tried for and convicted of Hannaâ€™s murder and all other related offenses.Â  He appeals all convictions.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.â€Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5-6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  We are bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  See State v. Abdullah, 357 S.C. 344, 349, 592 S.E.2d 344, 347 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œOn appeal from a suppression hearing, this court is bound by the circuit courtâ€™s factual findings if any evidence supports the findings.â€).Â  â€œOn review, we are limited to determining whether the trial judge abused his discretion.Â  This Court does not re-evaluate the facts based on its own view of the preponderance of the evidence but simply determines whether the trial judgeâ€™s ruling is supported by any evidence.â€Â  Wilson, 345 S.C. at 6, 545 S.E.2d at 829 (internal citations omitted).Â  The admission or exclusion of evidence is left to the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 557, 564 S.E.2d 87, 93 (2002).Â  A courtâ€™s ruling on the admissibility of evidence will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion or the commission of legal error, which results in prejudice to the defendant.Â  State v. Hamilton, 344 S.C. 344, 353, 543 S.E.2d 586, 591 (Ct. App. 2001) (overruled on other grounds by State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 610 S.E.2d 494 (2005)).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Immunity
Compton contends his agreement to cooperate in the investigation of the murder of Hanna granted him immunity from prosecution on any related charges.Â  We disagree.
Looking at the agreement, there is nothing to evidence an understanding between the parties that Compton could not be prosecuted for the Hanna murder.Â  It is generally recognized that immunity agreements and plea agreements are to be construed in accordance with general contract principles.Â  See U.S. v. Harvey, 791 F.2d 294, 300 (4th Cir. 1986) (â€œIn the process of determining whether disputed plea agreements have been formed or performed, courts have necessarily drawn on the most relevant body of developed rules
and principles of private law, those pertaining to the formation and interpretation of commercial contracts.â€).Â  Accordingly, this court should not read terms or conditions into the contract that the parties did not intend.Â  See Schulmeyer v. State Farm Fire & Cas. Co., 353 S.C. 491, 495, 579 S.E.2d 132, 134 (2003); McPherson v. J.E. Sirrine & Co., 206 S.C. 183, 204, 33 S.E.2d 501, 509 (1945).Â  The court must enforce an unambiguous contract according to its terms, regardless of the contractâ€™s wisdom or folly, or the partiesâ€™ failure to guard their rights carefully.Â  Ellis v. Taylor, 316 S.C. 245, 248, 449 S.E.2d 487, 488 (1994).Â  In Harvey, the court discussed the interpretation of immunity and plea agreements:Â  

Private law interpretive principles may be wholly dispositive in an appropriate case.Â  For example, whether a written agreement is ambiguous or unambiguous on its face should ordinarily be decided by the courts as a matter of law.Â  If it is unambiguous as a matter of law, and there is no suggestion of government overreaching of any kind, the agreement should be interpreted and enforced accordingly.Â  Neither side should be able, any more than would be private contracting parties, unilaterally to renege or seek modification simply because of uninduced mistake or change of mind.Â  

Harvey, at 300.
In the instant case, the agreement makes no mention of immunity from prosecution for any crime.Â  In fact the word immunity, or any variation thereof, is nowhere to be found in the four corners of the document.Â  â€œProsecutionâ€ is mentioned only once in relation to the Stateâ€™s â€œprosecutionâ€ of Compton for perjury if he lied to investigators.Â  The agreement is unambiguous.Â  It clearly indicates the Stateâ€™s intentionâ€”to get reliable information that could assist in solving the murder case.Â  Comptonâ€™s intention is equally clearâ€”to get a reduction in the sentences for his burglary convictions.Â  The burglary convictions are specifically referenced by indictment numbers, and the reduction sought is set forth in specific terms.Â  The agreement is simply a contract of cooperation between the parties.Â  To characterize the agreement as something more would be to read into it terms that simply are not there.Â  
Furthermore, there is no argument by Compton that the investigators overreached or coerced him into making the agreement.Â  It was entered into after Compton initiated contact with Sheriff Goodwin in the hopes of procuring a reduction on his already imposed burglary sentence.Â  There is no indication the agreement contemplated the granting of immunity from prosecution on charges relating to the Hanna murder in exchange for Comptonâ€™s testimony.Â  Accordingly, the trial court did not err in refusing to quash the indictments brought against Compton based upon this agreement. [2] 
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Rule 410, SCRE.
Compton contends the trial court erred in refusing to exclude his statements under Rule 410, SCRE, as the statements were made in the course of plea negotiations.Â  We disagree.
Rule 410 provides that evidence of a guilty plea that is later withdrawn or evidence of a plea of nolo contendere is inadmissible against a defendant.Â  Furthermore, statements made in the course of court proceedings related to such pleas are not admissible.Â  Likewise, a statement made during plea negotiations with a prosecuting authority, even if a guilty plea is not entered or is later withdrawn, is not admissible.
The unequivocal language of Rule 410 precludes its application in the instant case.Â  The discussions between Compton, the solicitor, and investigators were not in furtherance of Compton making a plea on any charges.Â  The discussions came after he already pled guilty to burglary charges and before any charges were brought related to the Hanna murder.Â  Nothing in the record indicates Compton ever offered to plead guilty or planned to plead guilty to the Hanna murder in exchange for anything from the State.Â  The only negotiations were related to the reduction in the sentence for the burglary charges.Â  Accordingly, the trial court did not err in refusing to exclude the statements under Rule 410, SCRE.
III.Â Â Â  Promise of LeniencyÂ Â Â  
Compton contends the trial court erred in failing to exclude his confessions on the grounds that they were made after a promise of leniency and were, therefore, not voluntary.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe test for determining the admissibility of a statement is whether it was knowingly, intelligently, and voluntarily given under the totality of the circumstances.Â  A statement induced by a promise of leniency is involuntary only if so connected with the inducement as to be a consequence of the promise.â€Â  State v. Owens, 346 S.C. 637, 660, 552 S.E.2d 745, 757 (2001) (overruled on other grounds by State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 610 S.E.2d 494 (2005)) (internal citations omitted).
In this case, the record indicates Compton was never told his statements would not be used against him.Â  Nothing brought out in the Jackson v. Denno[3] hearing or in the arguments to quash the indictments indicated Compton made the statements involuntarily and based upon a promise of leniency.Â  Additionally, he sought out the sheriff in order to make a deal to reduce his burglary sentence in exchange for information about a separate matter.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court properly concluded the statements were given knowingly and voluntarily by Compton and were properly presented to the jury for consideration.
IV.Â Â Â  Right to Counsel
Compton contends the court erred in failing to suppress his statements because the State violated his Sixth Amendment right to counsel by having Tracey Black initiate contact as a government informant.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe Sixth Amendment right [to counsel] attaches only â€˜post-indictment,â€™ at least in the questioning/statement setting.â€Â  State v. Council, 335 S.C. 1, 15, 515 S.E.2d, 508, 515 (1999) (citing Michigan v. Harvey, 494 U.S. 344 (1990)).Â  â€œThe Sixth Amendment right does not attach simply because the defendant has been arrested or because the investigation has focused on him.â€Â  State v. Register, 323 S.C. 471, 477, 476 S.E.2d 153, 157 (1996) (citing Hoffa v. United States, 385 U.S. 293 (1966)).Â  Furthermore, South Carolina follows the federal constitutional rule that the Sixth Amendment right to counsel is offense-specific; the mere fact counsel is appointed in one matter does not invoke the right to counsel in another, unrelated matter.Â  State v. Owens, 346 S.C. 637, 661, 552 S.E.2d 745, 758 (2001) (overruled on other grounds by State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 610 S.E.2d 494 (2005)).Â Â  
In the instant case, Compton was not indicted for the charges related to the Hanna murder until after he provided information to Black.Â  While he was represented on the unrelated burglary charges and at the making of the agreement, that fact does not give rise to a Sixth Amendment violation regarding information gathered about the Hanna murder.Â  Accordingly, the trial court properly admitted evidence of Comptonâ€™s statements at trial.Â  
V.Â Â Â Â Â  Examination of Witness
Compton contends the trial court erred in limiting his ability to examine Solicitor Jones.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe Sixth Amendment rights to notice, confrontation, and compulsory process guarantee that a criminal charge may be answered through the calling and interrogation of favorable witnesses, the cross-examination of adverse witnesses, and the orderly introduction of evidence.â€Â  State v. Graham, 314 S.C. 383, 385, 444 S.E.2d 525, 527 (1994).Â  â€œThis does not mean, however, that trial courts conducting criminal trials lose their usual discretion to limit the scope of cross-examination.â€Â  State v. Aleksey, 343 S.C. 20, 33-34, 538 S.E.2d 248, 255 (2000).Â  
Comptonâ€™s counsel sought to elicit testimony from Solicitor Jones to support the theory that the agreement called for Compton to be immune from prosecution in the Hanna murder.Â  Counsel also sought testimony about Jonesâ€™ belief that Comptonâ€™s attorney would continue to be involved in the case.Â  Such testimony was not relevant to the issue of Comptonâ€™s guilt or innocence.Â  The jury was not entitled to determine whether the agreement provided transactional immunity, as that was a question of contract interpretation before the court.Â  Additionally, the statement sought to be admitted to impeach the solicitor, while not relevant, was also based upon pure speculation that counsel would continue in his involvement.Â  As such, we find no error on the part of the trial court in limiting the examination of Solicitor Jones or in refusing to allow Compton to impeach Jones using a prior statement that was purely speculative.
CONCLUSION
We find the agreement is unambiguous and does not intend to grant immunity to Compton from prosecution on charges related to the Hanna murder.Â  Additionally, we find the statements given by Compton were properly admitted by the trial court.Â  We conclude there was no violation of Comptonâ€™s Sixth Amendment right to counsel by placing Black in the same prison cell to act as a conduit of information.Â  Finally, we find the limitation of Comptonâ€™s examination of Solicitor Jones was proper.Â  Accordingly, Comptonâ€™s convictions and sentences are 
AFFIRMED.
 KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Rule 410 generally discusses the inadmissibility of withdrawn pleas and statements made during plea negotiations.Â  
[2] Both parties also discuss in their briefs whether the agreement was breached and whether the State was required to honor the agreement.Â  The issue before this court is whether the agreement granted Compton immunity from prosecution based upon his cooperation and whether the trial court erred in refusing to quash the indictments.Â  We are therefore precluded from addressing any contention related to an alleged breach of the agreement.Â  
[3] 378 U.S. 368 (1964).

title: Doe v. Howe
description: John Doe appeals the grant of summary judgment in his action for legal malpractice and breach of fiduciary duty.
text:
Doe v. Howe # 13719


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
John Doe, Appellant,
v.
Gedney M. Howe, III, and Gedney M. Howe, III, P.A.,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Roger M. Young, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4061
Heard November 7, 2005 â€“ Filed December 19, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART, VACATED AND REMANDED IN PART


  
    
      
Desa A. Ballard, of West Columbia, for Appellant.
A. Camden Lewis, of Columbia, M. Dawes Cooke Jr. and James H. Elliott Jr., both of Charleston; for Respondents.
      
    
  

GOOLSBY, J.:Â  This appeal involves claims by the appellant John Doe against the respondents Gedney M. Howe, III, and Gedney M. Howe, III, P.A., for legal malpractice and breach of fiduciary duty.Â  The trial court granted summary judgment to Howe and his law firm.Â  Doe appeals.Â  We affirm the grant of summary judgment on Doeâ€™s action for legal malpractice, vacate the dismissal of Doeâ€™s action for breach of fiduciary duty, and remand the breach of fiduciary duty claim for a written order pursuant to our opinion in Bowen v. Lee Process Systems Co.[1]
FACTS
We set forth the facts below, as we must, viewed in the light most favorable to Doe, the party against whom the trial judge granted summary judgment.Â  We glean these facts from three sources:Â  the allegations of the pleadings, the testimony given in depositions, and the statements of fact given in affidavits.Â  We assume these facts are true only for the purpose of the summary judgment motion and determine merely whether they, when properly viewed, present triable issues.[2]
Doe, who was born September 2, 1962, is Howeâ€™s former client.Â  From 1968 to 1980, Doe attended Porter-Gaud, a private school in Charleston.Â  In 1977, Edward Fischer, a teacher at Porter-Gaud, began sexually molesting Doe.Â  At the time, Doe was fourteen years old and in the ninth grade.Â  Doe and Fischer continued to have sexual contact until 1982, two years after Doe became an adult and no longer attended Porter-Gaud.
Seventeen years later, in June 1999, Doe retained Howe and Howeâ€™s brother, Donald Howe, to represent him in an action against Porter-Gaud arising from the abuse Doe said Fischer inflicted upon him.Â  Howe expressed concern to Doe early on that the statute of limitations presented a problem and could prevent Doe from recovering on any claim against Porter-Gaud.Â  
Notwithstanding the statute of limitations, Porter-Gaud offered to settle Doeâ€™s claim.Â  Based upon Howeâ€™s advice and without filing suit, Doe settled with Porter-Gaud for $88,000 in May 2000.Â  A few months later, in October 2000, a parent of another of Fischerâ€™s victims received jury verdicts against Porter-Gaud and the estates of two former officials of the school totaling $105 million dollars.Â  The attorneys who obtained these verdicts had also succeeded in defeating summary judgment on at least four occasions.Â  
After learning of the verdicts, Doe contacted Donald Howe the following month to inquire about the possibility of rescinding his settlement with Porter-Gaud.Â  According to Doe, Donald Howe knew of no way to set aside the settlement, but nevertheless agreed to talk with his brother about the matter.Â  Doe stated he never received an answer to his inquiry from either Donald Howe or Gedney Howe.Â  
The attorneys who obtained the multi-million dollar verdict later settled all the sexual abuse cases brought against the Porter-Gaud defendants, with each student claimant receiving an average of $2 million dollars each.Â  
After Doe settled with Porter-Gaud, he discovered Howe had enrolled his son in Porter-Gaud during the time Howe had represented Doe.Â  Doe also learned Howe had made significant financial contributions to Porter-Gaud since 1996.Â  Howe never divulged to Doe these personal relationships with Porter-Gaud.Â  In addition, Doe learned in 2001 that Howe represented Porter-Gaud in a bad-faith action against its insurer regarding payment of claims made by Fischerâ€™s victims and their parents.
Doe then brought the present action.Â  The trial judge subsequently granted Howeâ€™s motion for summary judgment, holding that, because Doeâ€™s action against Porter-Gaud would have been untimely, Doe could not provide evidence that he â€œâ€˜most probablyâ€™ would have received a larger settlement than he didâ€ or that â€œhe â€˜most probablyâ€™ would have prevailed on the underlying claim at trial.â€Â  
In the same order, the trial judge denied a motion by Doe to recuse himself based on disclosures that (1) the judge had contacted Howe on an unrelated matter and (2) the judgeâ€™s law clerk had applied for a position with the law firm of one of Howeâ€™s attorneys.Â  
Doe filed this appeal after the trial judge denied his motion for reconsideration.
DISCUSSION
1.Â  Doe contends the trial judge abused his discretion in failing to disqualify himself.Â  
At the conclusion of the summary judgment hearing, the trial judge invited counsel for both parties to his chambers to disclose that he had previously contacted Howe to inquire whom his wife should contact to apply for a position at the new Charleston School of Law.Â  He did not, however, ask Howe to otherwise assist his wife in securing employment with the school and he did not know of anything that indicated Howe did in fact exercise any influence on her behalf.Â  
Two days after the hearing, the judge also disclosed to attorneys for the parties that his law clerk had an employment application pending with the law firm representing Howe.Â  He assured counsel he would not allow the law clerk to have any further involvement with the case for that reason.Â  
In support of his claim of judicial prejudice in this case, Doe argues (1) he was highly suspicious and mistrustful of people and the legal system because of his victimization by Fischer, Porter-Gaud, and Howe; (2) the trial judge â€œgratuitouslyâ€ included the issue of damages in his ruling; (3) Howe had already made an unsuccessful motion before another judge in this case for summary judgment on the ground of the running of the statute of limitations; and (4) the trial judgeâ€™s, to quote Doeâ€™s brief, â€œabhorrenceâ€ of deciding a matter involving an attorney influenced the judgeâ€™s decision in this case.
As to the first contention, we are not aware of any decision recognizing the emotional fragility of a litigant as a ground for mandatory disqualification of a trial judge.Â  Further, Doe cites no authority for this proposition in his brief.Â  In any case, we hold the emotional fragility of a litigant, without more, provides no basis for disqualification of a judge. 
As to the second contention, the mere fact that a judge includes an issue not raised by the parties does not indicate bias or prejudice.Â  It is not at all unusual for a judge to include in an order an issue not raised by a party.[3]Â  Besides, there are rules by which a party can challenge an order that includes matters not properly before the court.[4]Â  The record does not suggest that Doe attempted to avail himself of these procedures.
As to the third contention, the fact that a judge would reach an outcome different from that reached by another judge does not give rise to an inference of prejudice.Â  Judges differ all the time in their approach to the law.Â  One need only look at the number of dissenting and concurring opinions that sometimes accompany appellate court decisions or at the number of times an appellate court reverses the decisions of other tribunals.[5]
And as to the fourth contention, although the trial judge expressed a dislike of having to sit in judgment of lawyers, he also said â€œit is what judges must do.â€Â  Judging others is not an easy task.Â  Just because a judge may dislike having to make a decision in a particular kind of case does not translate into his or her being unable to make an impartial and well-reasoned decision.Â  What every litigant has a right to expect from a judge is that he or she be fair[6] and, to paraphrase the inscription that appears on the seal of this court, he or she give the litigant his or her due, no more and no less.Â  This we are satisfied the trial judge endeavored to do in this instance.Â  His acknowledgment of the grave responsibility that judges have in deciding cases tells us as much.
â€œUnder South Carolina law, if there is no evidence of judicial prejudice, a judgeâ€™s failure to disqualify himself will not be reversed on appeal.â€[7]Â  â€œIt is not enough for a party to allege bias; a party seeking disqualification of a judge must show some evidence of bias or prejudice.â€[8]Â  
Because Doe made no showing here of actual prejudice, we find no abuse of discretion in the trial judgeâ€™s refusal to disqualify himself.Â  If anything, the trial judge demonstrated sensitivity toward any concerns Doe might have had regarding his impartiality by voluntarily making full disclosure of his and his law clerkâ€™s contacts with Howe and Howeâ€™s counsel.
2.Â  Doe contends the trial judge improperly granted summary judgment on the basis that his underlying cause of action was barred by the statute of limitations.
As we understand from his brief, Doe contends that, under Rule 56 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure and Black v. Lexington School District No. 2,[9] the question of whether the statute of limitations barred his underlying action was a matter for jury determination.Â  He further contends evidence that â€œcompetent attorneys did, in fact, defeat summary judgment on the statute of limitations in cases exactly like [his case]â€ was sufficient to create a genuine issue of material fact as to whether the statute of limitations was an insurmountable bar to his claim against Porter-Gaud.Â  He makes no contention that a triable issue of fact exists regarding whether the statute of limitations would have been raised as an affirmative defense in the underlying action.[10]Â  
We recognize, as Doe argues, the supreme court in Black stated â€œthe issue of whether a defendant is estopped from claiming the statute of limitations is ordinarily a question of factâ€;[11] however, in the very same sentence in the opinion the court also noted that, nevertheless, â€œsummary judgment is appropriate where there is no evidence of conduct on the defendantâ€™s part warranting estoppel.â€[12]Â  We, too, hold that, although genuine issues of material fact regarding the applicability of the statute of limitations on an underlying case may prevent summary judgment on a legal malpractice action arising from that case, no such issues are present in this case.
To recover for legal malpractice, a plaintiff must prove the following:Â  (1) the existence of an attorney-client relationship, (2) a breach of duty by the attorney, (3) damage to the client, and (4) proximate cause of the clientâ€™s damages by the breach.[13]Â  As to damages, the plaintiff must show he or she â€œmost probably would have been successful in the underlying suit if the attorney had not committed the alleged malpractice.â€[14]Â  The question of the success of the underlying claim, if suit had been brought, is a question of law.[15]Â  
Doe testified Fischer molested him from 1977 until 1982.Â  Doe acknowledged he knew Fischerâ€™s actions were wrong when they occurred and said he had thought about what Fischer did to him at least once a day ever since the acts took place.Â  Even assuming each act of molestation gave rise to a distinct cause of action, the statute of limitations would have expired in 1988, six years after the last act of molestation in 1982, and more than ten years before Doe even retained Howe, which occurred in 1999.Â  
Because nothing in the record suggests that a dispute exists regarding any of the factual issues regarding the applicability of the statute of limitations in the underlying case, such as estoppel or some discrepancy as to the operative dates, we hold Doeâ€™s claim against Porter-Gaud, as a matter of law, had lapsed long before Howe undertook to represent him.[16]Â  The trial judge, therefore, correctly concluded Doe could not, as a matter of law, prove his claim of legal malpractice against Howe because the underlying action would not have been successful in that the statute of limitations would have barred Doe from maintaining it.[17]Â  
We further reject Doeâ€™s argument that, had he been aware of Howeâ€™s loyalties to Porter-Gaud, he would have dismissed Howe and hired another attorney who would have overcome the statute of limitations bar.Â  This argument provides at best only a subjective assessment of the viability of Doeâ€™s underlying action against Porter-Gaud.Â  The successful defeat of the statute of limitations defense in another case, even one involving a plaintiff who was substantially similar to Doe, does not create an issue of fact as to whether the statute of limitations had run on Doeâ€™s action against Porter-Gaud.[18]Â  
3.Â  Doe further argues the trial judge erred in concluding the expert opinions he presented did not create a genuine issue of material fact precluding summary judgment.Â  
The opinions on which Doe relied came from Gregory B. Adams, a professor at the University of South Carolina School of Law, and J. David Flowers, a Greenville attorney.Â  
According to Adams, (1) Howe had an obligation to disclose the relationship between himself and Porter-Gaud; (2) if Howe had informed Doe of the potential conflicts of interests regarding a lawsuit against Porter-Gaud, Doe would have retained the attorneys who were representing other plaintiffs suing Porter-Gaud; and (3) consequently, Doe would have shared in the lucrative settlement and recovered much more than what he agreed to accept on Howeâ€™s advice.Â  
Aside from whether we now need to address the question related to Adamsâ€™ affidavit because of our holding that the statute of limitations barred the underlying action, the question of whether the opinions offered by Adams created an issue of material fact in this case is not properly before us.Â  The trial judge did not address the impact of Adamsâ€™ statements, and Doe did not raise this issue in his motion for reconsideration. [19] 
Turning to the statements from Flowers, we agree with the trial judge that this expert witness did not assert anything that would create an issue of material fact warranting denial of summary judgment in this case.Â  
According to Flowers, â€œDoe most probably would have defeated Porter-Gaudâ€™s defenses if his case had been filed and zealously pursued.â€Â  In addition, Flowers noted that, until the present case, Porter-Gaud had been unsuccessful in obtaining dismissals of other claims arising from Fischerâ€™s misconduct.Â  He further stated his opinion was â€œnot â€˜mere speculation,â€™â€ but was â€œbased on the record and experience of the prior litigation which lasted years, and on the defendantsâ€™ apparently newfound belief in the strength of cases like Doeâ€™s.â€Â  
The trial judge held Flowersâ€™ statements were insufficient to defeat Howeâ€™s summary judgment motion because Flowers never explicitly stated Doe most probably would have recovered more than the $88,000 he received in his settlement with Porter-Gaud.Â  Doe takes issue with this holding, asserting he had to show only that he â€œmost probably would have been successfulâ€ in the underlying action but for the alleged malpractice and therefore did not need expert testimony regarding the amount that he would have recovered.Â  We disagree with both arguments.
Flowers based his statement that Doe most probably would have defeated Porter-Gaudâ€™s defenses on the experiences of other individuals who had asserted claims against Porter-Gaud.Â  As we pointed out earlier, the success of other plaintiffs, even those who might be similarly situated to Doe, is not an objective criterion on which to base an assertion that, had Doe filed a lawsuit on his underlying claim against Porter-Gaud, he would have defeated the statute of limitations defense and prevailed at trial.[20]
We further agree with the trial judgeâ€™s reliance on the fact that Flowers never stated â€œthat Doe â€˜most probablyâ€™ would have received more than the $88,000 he received in his settlement with Porter-Gaud.â€Â  It appears to us that the trial judge, in citing this factor, was not imposing an additional requirement for Doeâ€™s prima facie case, but rather, was considering an alternative course through which Doe could avoid summary judgment.[21]Â  As one commentator has aptly stated on this subject:

The clientâ€™s burden of establishing proximate cause in a legal malpractice action requires that he prove that he would have obtained a better result in the underlying matter if the attorney had exercised reasonable care.Â  The burden does not necessarily compel the client to demonstrate that he would have won the underlying case.Â  Rather, it is enough for the legal malpractice plaintiff to show that he has lost a valuable right; e.g., the settlement value of the underlying case.Â  Stated otherwise, â€œthe client need not show a perfect claim.Â  But the client must show at least that he has lost a probability of success as a result of the attorneyâ€™s negligence.â€[22]

Doeâ€™s counsel herself commented during oral argument to this court that numerous factors, including the statute of limitations, are considered to determine the settlement value of a claim.Â  Notably absent from the record in this case, however, is any mention of settlement value from Flowers or any other expert that was brought to the trial judgeâ€™s attention.Â  
As far as we can tell, the record contains only a â€œGross Distributionâ€ list showing that various claimants represented by other counsel each received approximately $2 million dollars following the initial verdict against the school.[23]Â  But this list does nothing more than set forth factual information.Â  Most certainly, the list does not constitute an opinion that Doe should have made a recovery similar to the other claimants.Â  At best, it could serve, if at all, only as evidence that could have supported an opinion regarding the settlement value of Doeâ€™s claim.[24]
4.Â  Finally, Doe argues his inability to maintain his cause of action for legal malpractice should not bar him from proceeding on his breach of fiduciary duty claim.Â  
The trial judge, as we interpret his order, dismissed both the legal malpractice claim and the breach of fiduciary duty claim because he viewed the record as presenting no triable issue of fact regarding whether Doe would have recovered more by either trial or settlement than $88,000 if he had retained a different lawyer or if Howe had represented him more â€œzealously.â€
Doe followed up with a post-hearing Rule 59(e) motion in which he contended, among other things, he could pursue a cause of action for breach of fiduciary duty without establishing that he would have succeeded on the underlying claim on which the legal malpractice action was based.Â  The trial judge denied Doeâ€™s motion in a summary order without further discussion of Doeâ€™s right to maintain an action for breach of fiduciary duty.Â  
In Bowen v. Lee Process Systems Co., this court stated the following regarding the trial courtâ€™s responsibility when issuing a summary judgment order:Â  

On appeal from the grant of summary judgment, an appellate court must determine whether the trial courtâ€™s stated grounds for its decision are supported by the record.Â  It is our duty to undertake a thorough and meaningful review of the trial courtâ€™s order and the entire record on appeal.Â  Where, as here, the trial court fails to articulate the reasons for its action on the record or enter a written order outlining its rationale, we simply cannot perform our designated function.[25]

Considering all the relevant circumstances, we do not fault the trial judge for his summary handling of Doeâ€™s post-hearing motion.Â  We are mindful of the demands on trial judges, especially when back-to-back scheduling of nonjury matters occurs.Â  We also recognize that, early on in the present case, the trial judge, in a conscientious effort to prevent a potential conflict of interest from tainting his decision, instructed his law clerk not to participate in the proceedings, thereby relinquishing assistance that would normally have been available to adjudicate a difficult and emotionally driven lawsuit.Â  Moreover, in all fairness to the trial judge, we acknowledge that, after our decision in Bowen, we stated in Clark v. South Carolina Department of Public Safety that â€œthere is no blanket requirement that the trial court set forth a separate explanation on all of its rulings on post-trial motions.â€[26]Â  
The order at issue in Clark, however, had been issued pursuant to post-trial motions following a hearing on the merits.Â  Of even greater significance is the fact that the reasoning behind the denial of the post-trial motions was discernible from the record on appeal.Â  In contrast, we are unable to glean any â€œstated groundsâ€ in this case from either the order denying reconsideration or the record on appeal as to why the trial judge rejected Doeâ€™s arguments concerning his breach of fiduciary duty claim.Â  At this point, we can only speculate about the reason the trial judge determined Doe could not proceed on this claim.Â  Despite a number of possible explanations[27] as to why the trial judge held as he did, we are reluctant to pass judgment on his ruling based on mere conjecture as to how he reached his decision.
We therefore vacate the dismissal of the breach of fiduciary duty cause of action and remand the matter to the trial judge for an order â€œidentifying the facts and accompanying legal analysis on which [he] reliedâ€[28] to enable a meaningful appellate review of this issue.
 AFFIRMED IN PART, VACATED AND REMANDED IN PART.
BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Bowen v. Lee Process Systems Co., 342 S.C. 232, 536 S.E.2d 86 (Ct. App. 2000).
[2]Â  See id. at 238, 536 S.E.2d at 89 (footnotes omitted) (stating that findings of fact for the purpose of summary judgment â€œare not factual findings in the ordinary sense as contemplated in our rules of procedureâ€ but â€œare statements made by the court as it views the evidence and its inferences in the light most favorable to the nonmoving partyâ€).
[3]Â  See, e.g., Lake v. Reeder Constr. Co., 330 S.C. 242, 248, 498 S.E.2d 650, 653 (Ct. App. 1998) (â€œLack of subject matter jurisdiction can be raised at any time, can be raised for the first time on appeal, and can be raised sua sponte by the court.â€).
[4]Â  See Rule 52(b), SCRCP (regarding motions to amend findings by the trial court) and id. Rule 59(e) (regarding motions to alter or amend judgments).
[5]Â  See Reading v. Ball, 291 S.C. 492, 495, 354 S.E.2d 397, 399 (Ct. App. 1987) (â€œThe fact a judge rules against a litigant is not proof of prejudice by the judge, even if it is later held the judge committed error in his ruling.â€).
[6]Â  See Mallett v. Mallett, 323 S.C. 141, 147, 473 S.E.2d 804, 808 (Ct. App. 1996) (â€œIt is axiomatic that the expectation of a fair and impartial tribunal is a basic tenet of all cherished notions of due process embodied in the United States Constitution.â€).
[7]Â  Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 524, 599 S.E.2d 114, 118 (2004).
[8]Â  Christensen v. Mikell, 324 S.C. 70, 74, 476 S.E.2d 692, 694 (1996).
[9]Â  327 S.C. 55, 488 S.E.2d 327 (1997).
[10] See Rule 8(c), SCRCP (listing the statute of limitations among the defenses a party â€œshall set forth affirmativelyâ€ in a responsive pleading).
[11] Black, 327 S.C. at 61, 488 S.E.2d at 330.
[12] Id.
[13] Brown v. Theos, 345 S.C. 626, 629, 550 S.E.2d 304, 306 (2001); Hall v. Fedor, 349 S.C. 169, 174, 561 S.E.2d 654, 656 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
[14] Summer v. Carpenter, 328 S.C. 36, 42, 492 S.E.2d 55, 58 (1997).Â  
[15] See Manning v. Quinn, 294 S.C. 383, 386, 365 S.E.2d 24, 25 (1988) (holding in a legal malpractice case that the likelihood of success of action that the plaintiff alleged the defendant should have taken was a question of law â€œand decision of that question on summary judgment motion is appropriateâ€).
[16] Cf. Doe v. Crooks, 364 S.C. 349, 352, 613 S.E.2d 536, 538 (2005) (holding that, because the plaintiffâ€™s cause of action for sexual molestation had lapsed because of the expiration of the statute of limitations, it could not be â€œrevivedâ€ by the enactment of a new statute of limitations that redefines the date at which the limitations period begins to run).
[17] See Kreutner v. David, 320 S.C. 283, 285-86, 465 S.E.2d 88, 90 (1995) (â€œThe date on which discovery should have been made is an objective, not subjective, question.â€).
[18] See Wilburn Brewer, Jr., Expert Testimony in Legal Malpractice Cases, 45 S.C. L. Rev. 727, 766 (1994) (â€œUnder the case-within-a-case concept, the test is objective. Â Therefore, the test is not what the outcome would have been, but rather what is should have been.â€).
[19] See Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 122, 124 (1991) (holding that, when the trial court does not explicitly rule on a question and the appellant fails to move to alter or amend the judgment on that ground, the issue is not properly before the court of appeals and should not be addressed).
[20] See Brewer, supra note 18.
[21] See Hall, 349 S.C. at 175, 561 S.E.2d at 657 (noting the plaintiff in a legal malpractice case could defeat the defendant attorneyâ€™s summary judgment motion by establishing that he most probably would have received a larger settlement than what he agreed to accept while represented by the defendant or that he most probably would have prevailed on the underlying claim had there been a trial).
[22] David A. Barry, Legal Malpractice in Massachusetts:Â  Recent Developments, 78 Mass. L. Rev. 74, 79 (1993) (footnotes omitted).Â  The quoted language is from Colucci v. Rosen,Goldberg, Slavet, Levenson & Wekstein, 515 N.E.2d 891, 895 (1987).
[23] The trial judge refused to consider this evidence on the grounds that it was not submitted in a timely fashion and was not in proper form.Â  
[24] See 31A Am. Jur. 2d Expert and Opinion Evidence Â§ 1, at 27 (2002) (â€œ[A]n expertâ€™s purpose is to provide an opinion about a disputed issue.â€).
[25] Bowen, 342 S.C. at 235-36, 536 S.E.2d at 87-88.
[26] Clark v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Pub. Safety, 353 S.C. 291, 312, 578 S.E.2d 16, 26 (Ct. App. 2002), affâ€™d, 362 S.C. 377, 608 S.E.2d 573 (2005).

General Sec. Ins. Co. v. Jordan, Coyne & Savits, LLP, 357 F. Supp. 2d 951, 961-62 (E.D. Fucile, Why Conflicts Matter, 48-SEP Advocate (Idaho) 23, 23-24 (2005) (stating that, even though a lawyer can perform â€œflawlessly in a technical sense,â€ if the services â€œresult in damage to a client flowing from a conflict, the client has a remedy against the lawyer under a theory of breach of fiduciary dutyâ€). title: In The Matter of Betsy M. Campbell
description: This appeal stems from a probate court action in which Daughter sought to have herself appointed as conservator of Mother's assets.  After appointing two doctors to examine Mother's capacity to handle her own affairs, the probate court denied Daughter's request to be appointed conservator.  Daughter appealed to the circuit court, which set the order aside, finding the doctors who examined Mother were not disinterested.  We affirm.
text:
In re Campbell


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
In The Matter of Betsy M. Campbell, Robert S. Campbell, Jr. 

Mary Schuyler Campbell, Respondent,
v.
Betsy M. Campbell and Robert S. Campbell, Jr., of whom Betsy M. Campbell is
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Cherokee County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. Â 4062
Heard November 9, 2005 â€“ Filed December 19, 2005Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
James R. Thompson, of Gaffney, R. David Massey, E. Zachary Horton, all of Greenville and William E. Winter, Jr., of Gaffney, for Appellant.
Randall S. Hiller, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.: This appeal stems from a probate court action in which Mary Schuyler Campbell (Daughter) sought to have herself appointed as conservator of Betsy M. Campbellâ€™s (Mother) assets.Â  After appointing two doctors to examine Motherâ€™s capacity to handle her own affairs, the probate court denied Daughterâ€™s request to be appointed conservator.Â  Daughter appealed to the circuit court, which set the order aside, finding the doctors who examined Mother were not disinterested.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
On February 28, 2002, Daughter filed a petition seeking to be appointed conservator of Motherâ€™s assets.Â  According to Daughter, Motherâ€™s assets exceeded sixty million dollars, and Mother needed a conservator because she â€œis no longer mentally capable of caring for [herself] or [her] assets due to Alzheimer disease and/or dementia and [her] assets are being given away to others who are exerting undue influence over [her].â€Â  Mother filed an answer, denying her need for a conservator and arguing that in the event she needed a conservator, William W. Brown would have priority over her daughter because he is her attorney in fact.Â  
After filing her petition, Daughter sent a discovery request to Mother, seeking copies of all of Motherâ€™s financial transactions from 1999 to 2002, all of Motherâ€™s income tax returns from 1999 to 2002, copies of any documents evidencing the transfer of property from Mother to William W. Brown, and all documents evidencing personal property owned by Mother.Â  In response to this request, Mother sent Daughter a copy of a deed, showing Mother had transferred a condominium to Brown for the sum of ten dollars.Â  Other than this deed, Mother refused to comply with Daughterâ€™s discovery requests, arguing they were not only overly broad, but also irrelevant because Daughter had not made a prima facie showing of Motherâ€™s incompetence.Â  
Because Mother had not fully complied with the discovery request, Daughter filed a motion seeking to compel production.Â  On July 9, 2002, the probate court had a hearing on the motion.Â  After denying Daughterâ€™s motion, the probate court directed Motherâ€™s counsel to prepare the order.Â  Counsel complied, and the court signed the order on August 12, 2002. That same day, the probate court also executed an order appointing Dr. Preston Edwards and Dr. John Cathcart as examiners for Mother.Â  Mother had previously designated these very doctors as her expert witnesses.Â  
Daughter argued the doctors were appointed without her input, and she did not learn of their appointment until she received the order, which was sent to her by Motherâ€™s counsel rather than by the court.Â  By the time Daughter received the order, arrangements had already been made with the doctors to fly them via private jet to Motherâ€™s home in Florida.Â  Mother paid the doctors about $2,000 each for their time and also paid for the cost of their transportation.Â  Brown accompanied the doctors during their entire trip.
Upon learning of the doctorsâ€™ appointment, Daughter filed a motion to reconsider both the probate courtâ€™s order denying her motion to compel discovery and its order appointing examiners.Â  The probate court held a hearing on the motions, and at the end of the hearing, Daughter moved that the probate judge recuse himself from the case.Â  Both the motion to reconsider and the motion to recuse were denied. 
After denying Daughterâ€™s motions, the probate court proceeded to hear the matter on its merits.Â  At the hearing, the doctors each testified that they spent an afternoon with Mother and found her to be completely competent to handle her own financial affairs.Â  In an affidavit he submitted to the court, Dr. Cathcart admitted to being a friend of Motherâ€™s for over sixty years, attending her husbandâ€™s most recent birthday party, and having supper with Mother four months prior to examining her.Â  According to Dr. Edwardsâ€™ affidavit, he had also eaten supper with Mother four months prior to examining her and before that, she had occasionally consulted him from 1950 to 1995 if she was having medical problems.Â  
Based on the doctorsâ€™ affidavits and their testimony at the hearing, the probate court found Mother to be mentally competent and therefore capable of handling her own finances.Â  Accordingly, the probate court found there was no need to appoint a conservator for Motherâ€™s assets.Â  
Daughter appealed to the circuit court, arguing among other things, that: (1) the order appointing examiners resulted from improper ex parte communications, (2) the probate court erred in appointing the doctors who were not disinterested parties, (3) the probate court judge erred in not recusing himself, and (4) the probate court erred in finding Mother was mentally competent.Â  The circuit court set aside the probate courtâ€™s order, finding the probate court abused its discretion in naming Drs. Cathcart and Edwards as examiners when Mother had previously designated them as expert witnesses on her behalf.Â  The circuit court also found the probate judgeâ€™s order and the personal comments he directed at Daughterâ€™s counsel demonstrated an improper prejudice against Daughterâ€™s case, and therefore, the circuit court recused the probate judge from the case. Because the probate judge who had heard the case was the only probate judge in Cherokee County, the circuit court ordered the case be transferred to Spartanburg County Probate Court.Â  Mother appeals.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Mother argues the circuit court erred in finding the probate courtâ€™s appointment of Drs. Cathcart and Edwards was an abuse of discretion.[1]Â  We disagree.
According to section 62-5-401 of the South Carolina Code (1987), the probate court may appoint a conservator to the estate and affairs of a person if the court determines: (1) the person is unable to manage his or her affairs due to advanced age or mental deficiency, and (2) the person has property that will be wasted unless proper management is provided.Â  To aid the court in determining whether a person lacks the mental capacity to handle his or her own affairs, section 62-5-407(b) requires the person â€œbe examined by one or more physicians designated by the court, preferably physicians who are not connected with any institution in which the person is a patient or is detained.â€
Mother argues the physicians appointed by the probate court were sufficient despite the fact she had previously designated them as her experts because the probate code does not restrict examiners to â€œdisinterestedâ€ physicians.Â  Mother points out that the statute merely states a preference for examiners who are not connected with an institution in which the person is a patient or is detained, neither of which are present in this case as Mother is not a patient in any institution.
While the statute does not specifically address whether a physician must be â€œdisinterestedâ€ or not, the obvious purpose of appointing examiners is to provide the probate court with a medical opinion regarding the personâ€™s mental capacity, and it is inherent that such an opinion come from a neutral physician.Â  The statuteâ€™s preference that the physician be independent from institutions in which the person is a patient evidences the Legislatureâ€™s desire for neutralilty.Â  Furthermore, in other court proceedings in which the trial court receives information from an intermediary, independence is required.Â  See, e.g., Doe v. Ward Law Firm, 353 S.C. 509, 519, 579 S.E.2d 303, 308 (2003) (holding that it was in an adopted childâ€™s best interests to appoint an intermediary to review law firmâ€™s adoption file for information relating to childâ€™s physical and psychological problems, and requiring intermediary to be independent of any party to the suit); Wrenn v. Wrenn, 228 SC. 588, 591, 91 S.E.2d 267, 268 (1956) (modifying trial courtâ€™s order dissolving partnership and remanding case for a â€œcompetent, disinterested and impartial personâ€ to be appointed as receiver). 
Here, Mother had previously designated Drs. Cathcart and Edwards as experts.Â  Thus, it was a foregone conclusion those doctors would opine Mother was capable of handling her own financial affairs.Â  By appointing such doctors to aid the court in determining Motherâ€™s mental capacity, the probate court merely went through the motions of following section 62-5-407.Â  Such a charade was not what the General Assembly intended in enacting the probate code.Â  We therefore find the probate court erred by appointing Drs. Cathcart and Edwards as examiners.Â  Because this error impacted the probate courtâ€™s subsequent order finding Mother was not in need of a conservator, the circuit court was correct to set that order aside as well.Â  Accordingly, the order of the circuit court is 
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] Mother also argues the circuit court erred in recusing the probate judge from further participation in this matter.Â  However, Mother concedes this issue has been rendered moot because the probate judge passed away during the pendency of this appeal.Â  Therefore, we need not address the issue.
