title: Doe v. ATC, Inc.
description: This is a negligent supervision case presenting the issue of whether an employer had adequate notice of its need to exercise control over an employee who sexually assaulted a disabled female passenger on a bus.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
2003-CP-23-2255
Sharon Doe, as Special Conservator for her daughter, Audra Doe,
Appellant,
v.
ATC, Inc., Transportation Management Services, Inc., and
Multisystems, Inc., Respondents.
______________________
2003-CP-23-2256 
Sharon Doe, as Special Conservator for her daughter, Audra Doe,
Appellant,
v.
Calvin Murray, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4063
Heard November 8, 2005 â€“ Filed December 19, 2005Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
John Robert Peace, of Greenville, for Appellant.
Maureen Z. White, of Greenville and Michael H. Montgomery, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.:Â  This is an appeal from the granting of a directed verdict in a negligent retention action.Â  The dispositive issue, as narrowly framed in the trial court, is whether a jury question existed as a result of the employerâ€™s decision not to fire an employee based on the report of a single incident of an inappropriate sexual advance toward a fellow employee.Â  We agree with the trial court that a jury question was not created by the employerâ€™s decision to retain the employee.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS[1]
Appellant Sharon Doe[2] is the mother of Audra Doe, a disabled adult female.Â  Audra rode a Medicaid bus to physical therapy sessions and to Greenville Memorial Hospital, where she did volunteer work.Â  Calvin Murray, an employee of Respondents (collectively â€œATCâ€) drove the Medicaid bus on which Audra sometimes rode.Â  While Audra was on the bus, Murray repeatedly touched her legs inappropriately, kissed her and made persistent comments to her of a sexual nature over a period of several months.Â  
Doe filed separate lawsuits on behalf of Audra against Murray and ATC.Â  These suits were consolidated and tried together.Â  Doeâ€™s claim against ATC was based on a negligent retention theory.[3]Â  
The trial court directed a verdict in favor of ATC.Â  The action against Murray resulted in a jury verdict of $1,000.Â  Doe appeals only from the direction of a verdict in favor of ATC, and there is no challenge in connection with the action against Murray.Â  Concerning the negligent retention theory of liability against ATC, Doe contended that Murray should have previously been fired due to an earlier, isolated incident involving a fellow employee, Tycie Moss.Â Â Â  
Moss testified that several months before the incidents involving Audra, Murray made an inappropriate advance toward her.Â  Mossâ€™s car had broken down, so Murray picked her up before her shift, around 3 or 4 oâ€™clock in the morning.Â  Moss got out of Murrayâ€™s van and, as she was getting into her van, Murray approached her, and â€œthen grabbed [her] arms â€¦ like he was forcing [her] to kiss him.â€Â  Moss pushed him away before he could kiss her, got into her van, and left.Â  Moss also testified that Murray made inappropriate sexual comments to her in the presence of clients on the van.Â  
Moss reported the incident to her supervisor, Hattie Wright.Â  Moss, however, told Wright not to write up a formal complaint against Murray because she â€œdidnâ€™t want it to blow up.â€Â  ATC had a formal complaint procedure that provided for an investigation of a complaint, but Moss refused to file a complaint.Â  In fact, Moss did not want Wright â€œto do anything about [the incident].â€Â  Wright said that Moss wanted her disclosure to remain in confidence, noting that Moss did not want Wright to â€œsay anything to anyone.â€Â Â Â  
Wright ignored Mossâ€™s wishes and pursued the matter the same day, initially by speaking with Murray.Â  Murray gave â€œhis sideâ€ and said the incident was not as â€œinterpreted.â€ Without an admission from Murray and the lack of a formal complaint, Wright nevertheless issued Murray a verbal warning, instructing him to â€œkeep [his] distanceâ€ and to â€œdo [his] job.â€Â  Also on the same day, Wright discussed the incident with her supervisor, Audlyn Williams, who was the manager in charge of the Greenville office. Â Williams believed that in light of Murrayâ€™s otherwise laudable employment recordâ€”he â€œnever had a [problem] beforeâ€â€”Wrightâ€™s actions were appropriate.Â  Wright subsequently prepared a memorandum for the file regarding the incident.Â Â Â  
It is undisputed that ATCâ€”prior to Doeâ€™s complaint on behalf of Audraâ€”had no other knowledge of inappropriate conduct of any kind by Murray. 
After Doe filed her complaint, Williams and Wright notified Melville Padgett, the general manager for ATCâ€™s Medicaid properties in South Carolina.Â  Padgett testified he was satisfied with Wrightâ€™s earlier actions because prior to the present action Murray had a â€œclean recordâ€ except for the single incident reported by Moss.Â  Following Doeâ€™s complaint, Murray admitted making an inappropriate comment to Audra on the bus, and Padgett fired him.Â  
 The Directed Verdict Motion
ATC moved for a directed verdict, and the trial court engaged in a lengthy discussion with Doeâ€™s counsel in an effort to determine the precise allegation of negligence against ATC.Â  Specifically, it was not clear what Doe claimed ATC should have done differently following the reported incident involving Moss.Â  The answer eventually surfaced:

The Court:Â  So they would have to have fired him [following the report by Moss]?
[Doeâ€™s counsel]:Â  Yes, sir.

The trial court, as noted, directed a verdict in favor of ATC.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In reviewing a motion for directed verdict, the appellate court applies the same standard as the circuit court.Â  Welch v. Epstein, 342 S.C. 279, 299, 536 S.E.2d 408, 418 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  The court must view the evidence and the inferences that can reasonably be drawn in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Sabb v. South Carolina State Univ., 350 S.C. 416, 427, 567 S.E.2d 231, 236 (2002).Â  If the evidence as a whole is susceptible of more than one reasonable inference, a jury issue is created and the motion should be denied.Â  Adams v. G.J. Creel & Sons, Inc., 320 S.C. 274, 277, 465 S.E.2d 84, 85 (1995); Bailey v. Segars, 346 S.C. 359, 366, 550 S.E.2d 910, 913 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS 
Doe argues that ATC negligently retained Murray by failing to fire him following the report by Moss.Â  The issue before us, as framed in the trial court and stipulated at oral argument, is a narrow oneâ€”was a jury question presented on Doeâ€™s theory of liability that ATC was negligent in not firing Murray following the attempted kissing incident involving a fellow employee?Â  We join the circuit court in answering the question â€œno.â€ 
We have canvassed the record and conclude that ATCâ€™s decision not to fire Murray following the incident with Moss was reasonable as a matter of law.Â  Doe makes no claim that ATCâ€™s supervision of Murray was negligent following the incident with Moss.Â  Cf. Degenhart v. Knights of Columbus, 309 S.C. 114, 116-17, 420 S.E.2d 495, 496 (1992) (recognizing the tort of negligent supervision in South Carolina law); Moore by Moore v. Berkeley County School Dist., 326 S.C. 584, 590, 486 S.E.2d 9, 12-13 (Ct. App. 1997) (examining negligent supervision case law since Degenhart).[4]Â  We can find no South Carolina case on point, and none has been cited.Â  South Carolina, indeed, recognizes the tort of negligent retention in the context of a negligent supervision action.Â  We have no pause in concluding our supreme court would recognize the tort of negligent retention, independent of allegations of negligent supervision.Â  See e.g., Yunker v. Honeywell, Inc., 496 N.W.2d 419, 422 (Minn. Ct. App. 1993) (holding that negligent hiring and negligent retention are distinct theories of recovery separate from negligent supervision).Â  In addressing the law of negligent supervision, our supreme court has cited with approval the Restatement (Second) of Torts Â§ 317 (1965).Â  Degenhart, 309 S.C. at 116-17, 420 S.E.2d at 496.Â  Comment c to section 317 of the Restatement (Second) of Torts deals specifically with the retention of employees, and provides, in relevant part:

c. Retention in employment of servants known to misconduct themselves. There may be circumstances in which the only effective control which the master can exercise over the conduct of his servant is to discharge the servant. Therefore the master may subject himself to liability under the rule stated in this Section by retaining in his employment servants who, to his knowledge, are in the habit of misconducting themselves in a manner dangerous to others.Â  

Our review of negligent hiring and retention cases from other jurisdictions leads us to conclude that such cases generally turn on two fundamental elementsâ€”knowledge of the employer and foreseeability of harm to third parties. Di Cosala v. Kay, 450 A.2d 508, 516 (N.J. 1982).Â  These elements, from a factual perspective, are not necessarily mutually exclusive, as a fact bearing on one element may also impact resolution of the other element.Â  From a practical standpoint, these elements are analyzed in terms of the number and nature of prior acts of wrongdoing by the employee, and the nexus or similarity between the prior acts and the ultimate harm caused.Â  Such factual considerationsâ€”especially questions related to proximate cause inherent in the concept of foreseeabilityâ€”will ordinarily be determined by the factfinder, and not as a matter of law.Â  Hoke v. May Depâ€™t Stores Co., 891 P.2d 686, 691 (Or. Ct. App. 1995); Gaines v. Monsanto Co., 655 S.W.2d 568, 571 (Mo. Ct. App. 1983).Â  Nevertheless, the court should dispose of the matter on a dispositive motion when no reasonable factfinder could find the risk foreseeable or the employerâ€™s conduct to have fallen below the acceptable standard.Â  Hoke, 891 P.2d at 690; Reed v. Kelly, 37 S.W.3d 274, 278 (Mo. Ct. App. 2000).Â  We believe Doeâ€™s claim against ATC is properly resolved as a matter of law.Â  
The standard, according to the Restatement section 317 comment c, is whether the employer knew the offending employee was â€œin the habit of misconducting [himself] in a manner dangerous to others.â€Â  Accordingly, many courts have recognized that a plaintiff must demonstrate some propensity, proclivity, or course of conduct sufficient to put the employer on notice of the possible danger to third parties.Â  See e.g., Frye v. Am. Painting Co., 642 N.E.2d 995, 999 (Ind. Ct. App. 1994) (holding that an employer may be held negligent if it retains an employee it knew or should have known had a propensity for dangerous behavior); Alpharetta First United Methodist Church v. Stewart, 472 S.E.2d 532, 536 (Ga. Ct. App. 1996) (holding that an employer may not be held liable for negligent hiring or retention unless the plaintiff shows the employer knew or should have known of the employeeâ€™s dangerous propensities); Gomez v. City of New York, 758 N.Y.S.2d 298, 299 (N.Y. App. Div. 2003) (â€œ[R]ecovery on a negligent hiring and retention theory requires a showing that the employer was on notice of the relevant tortious propensities of the wrongdoing employee.â€).Â  
Based on this requirement, some courts have dismissed negligent hiring and negligent retention claims when the claim rests on a single prior incident of misconduct.Â  For example, in Sullivan v. St. Louis Station Assocs., 770 S.W.2d 352 (Mo. Ct. App. 1989), the court held that a single prior incident was insufficient as a matter of law to establish negligent retention.Â  The Sullivan court noted that â€œthe plaintiff must demonstrate that the employee had dangerous proclivities . . . which denotes a course of conduct rather than a single aberration of behavior.â€Â  Id. at 357.Â  Similarly, in Moore v. Hosier, 43 F. Supp. 2d 978, 993-994 (N.D. Ind. 1998), the United States District Court for the Northern District of Indiana granted summary judgment to an employer in a negligent hiring and retention claim that was predicated on a single, prior incident.Â  The court observed that a single incident does not equate to a habit or propensity toward misconduct.Â  Id. at 993.Â  
However, we do not view the â€œhabit of misconductingâ€ language in the Restatement as mandating multiple prior acts of misconduct for a negligent retention action to remain viable in South Carolina.Â  We hold that a single isolated incident of prior misconduct (of which the employer knew or should have known) may support a negligent retention claim, provided the prior misconduct has a sufficient nexus to the ultimate harm.Â  In Doe v. Greenville Hosp. Sys., 323 S.C. 33, 40-41, 448 S.E.2d 564, 568 (Ct. App. 1994), in the context of a negligent supervision claim, this court affirmed the denial of the employerâ€™s directed verdict motionâ€”and hence a jury question was presentedâ€”where the prior isolated incident involved the same sexual misconduct against the same victim.
Turning to the case at hand, the prior alleged misconduct by Murray against Moss, a co-employee, lacks a sufficient nexus to the sexual assault on Audra.Â  While it is true that both incidents may generally be described as sexual in nature, the totality of the prior incident is a far cry from the reprehensible, persistent pattern of abuse against Audra.Â  If Mossâ€™s allegation against Murray were founded,[5] then Murrayâ€™s conduct involving Moss certainly deserved some form of disciplinary action.Â  ATC could have taken any number of actions, such as transferring Murray or requiring counseling.Â  However, none of these possibilities are in play here, because we are not confronted with any claim of negligent supervision, but only the claim that ATC should have fired Murray.Â  
Doeâ€™s laser-beam approachâ€”Murray had to be firedâ€”is simply not reasonable under the facts presented, including the nature of the incident involving Moss, Mossâ€™s unwillingness to file a formal complaint, and the complete absence of evidence of other such similar conduct by Murray.Â  Indeed, but for the allegation by Moss, Murray had a â€œcleanâ€ work record. Imposition of liability against an employer for negligent retention under these facts is legally untenable.Â  This court in no manner condones Murrayâ€™s purported misconduct against Moss, and we recognize that a single assault may well create a jury question as to whether an employee should be fired.Â  But this is not such a case. 
CONCLUSION
We find that the directed verdict for ATC was appropriate under the facts presented and the theory of liability advanced by Doe.Â  A reasonable jury could not conclude, based on the incident involving Moss, that ATC knew or should have known that Murray was likely to commit a sexual assault sometime in the future.Â  The decision to retain Murray following the informal report by Moss was reasonable as a matter of law.Â  The order of the trial court is 
AFFIRMED. 
STILWELL and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We adhere to the appropriate standard of review and thus view the facts in a light most favorable to Appellant, although the facts necessary for resolution of this appeal are largely undisputed.
[2] We have substituted the name Doe due to the nature of the allegations.
[3] The complaint alleged negligent supervision, but the case was tried as one of negligent retention. 
[4] In Appellantsâ€™ Final Brief, Doe seeks to recast the case as one of negligent supervision, arguing that ATC was â€œon noticeâ€ about the incident with Moss and hence the need to â€œexercise controlâ€ over Murray.Â  Issue preservation rules preclude us from expanding the case and issues beyond those argued in the trial court.Â  Counsel for Doe conceded at oral argument that the case against ATC rested solely on the claim that ATC was required to fire Murray following the incident with Moss. When properly viewed, Doe has defined and equated ATCâ€™s duty to â€œexercise controlâ€ with a duty to fire Murray. 
[5] We decline Doeâ€™s invitation to view Mossâ€™s allegation in hindsight through the lens of Murrayâ€™s abuse of Audra.

title: Peek v. Spartanburg Regional Healthcare System
description: This is an appeal from an order of the trial court enjoining Spartanburg Regional Healthcare System from terminating the staff privileges of anesthesiologist Sharon Peek until the merits of her case can be adjudicated.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Sharon K. Peek, M.D., Respondent,
v.
Spartanburg Regional Healthcare System, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge

AFFIRMED

Opinion No. 4064
Heard November 10, 2005 â€“ Filed December 19, 2005


  
    
      
Perry D. Boulier, of Spartanburg, for Appellant.
James C. Cothran, Jr., of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  This is an appeal from an order of the trial court enjoining Spartanburg Regional Healthcare System (the Hospital) from terminating the staff privileges of anesthesiologist Sharon Peek until the merits of her case can be adjudicated.Â Â  We affirm.Â Â  
FACTS
Peek is a licensed anesthesiologist.[1]Â  She has maintained staff privileges at the Hospital for almost fourteen years.Â  On January 30, 2004, general counsel for the Hospital informed Peek that pursuant to a prospective agreement between the Hospital and Foothills Anesthesia Consultants, P.C. (Foothills), Peek would lose her staff privileges at the Hospital unless she was employed by Foothills.Â  Although Peek did not wish to work at Foothills, she nevertheless sought employment there.Â  Foothills declined to employ her.Â  
On February 1, 2004, the Hospital entered into an â€œAnesthesiology Services Agreementâ€ with Foothills (2004 Agreement), which provided that Foothills â€œshall be the exclusive provider of Servicesâ€ at the Hospital.Â  This meant that core anesthesia servicesâ€”essentially, all anesthesia services outside of chronic pain managementâ€”could be performed only by employees of Foothills.Â  Accordingly, under the 2004 Agreement, if Foothills did not employ Peek, she could not practice core anesthesia services at the Hospital.Â  
On February 24, 2004, Peek was asked about her employment status with Foothills.Â  Because Foothills did not employ Peek, the Hospital acted under the 2004 Agreement and terminated her core anesthesia privileges.Â  On March 1, 2004, the President of the Hospital told Peek that effective March 6, 2004, she would no longer be allowed to perform any core anesthesia services at the Hospital.Â  On March 5, 2004, a day before Peekâ€™s privileges terminated, Peek sought a temporary restraining order to prevent the Hospital from revoking her core anesthesia privileges.Â  Peek also brought a breach of contract action against the Hospital for failing to follow its own bylaws when it terminated Peekâ€™s privileges.Â  
The trial court granted the temporary restraining order finding Peek made a prima facie showing she was entitled to protection under the Hospital bylaws.Â  The Hospital appeals from this temporary injunction.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The grant or denial of an injunction by the trial court will not be reversed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Gilley v. Gilley, 327 S.C. 8, 11-12, 488 S.E.2d 310, 312 (1997); MailSource, L.L.C. v. M.A. Bailey & Assocs., 356 S.C. 363, 367, 588 S.E.2d 635, 637-38 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the decision of the trial court is unsupported by the evidence or controlled by an error of law.Â  Ledford v. Pa. Life Ins. Co., 267 S.C. 671, 675, 230 S.E.2d 900, 902 (1976); County of Richland v. Simpkins, 348 S.C. 664, 668, 560 S.E.2d 902, 904 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
The sole issue on appeal is whether the trial court abused its discretion in granting Peek injunctive relief until the merits of her case can be heard.Â  We find no abuse of discretion. 
â€œAn injunction is a drastic remedy issued by the court in its discretion to prevent irreparable harm suffered by the plaintiff.â€Â  Scratch Golf Co. v. Dunes W. Residential Golf Props., Inc., 361 S.C. 117, 121, 603 S.E.2d 905, 907 (2004).Â  To obtain an injunction, the plaintiff must allege facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action for injunction and demonstrate the injunction is reasonably necessary to protect the legal rights pending in the litigation.Â  County of Richland v. Simpkins, 348 S.C. 664, 669, 560 S.E.2d 902, 904 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  To establish a cause of action for injunction, the plaintiff must show â€œ(1) it would suffer irreparable harm if the injunction is not granted; (2) it will likely succeed on the merits of the litigation; and (3) there is an inadequate remedy at law.â€Â  Scratch Golf, 361 S.C. at 121, 603 S.E.2d at 908.
A.Â Â Â Â Â  Irreparable Harm
The Hospital argues Peek has not suffered irreparable harm entitling her to injunctive relief because the harm she alleges can be remedied by monetary damages alone.Â  We disagree. 
Whether â€œa wrong is irreparable, in the sense that equity may intervene, and whether there is an adequate remedy at law, are questions that are not decided by narrow and artificial rules.â€Â  Kirk v. Clark, 191 S.C. 205, 211, 4 S.E.2d 13, 16 (1939).Â  Before granting an injunction, the trial court should balance the equities: the court should look at the particular facts of each case and the equities of each party and determine which side, if any, is more entitled to equitable relief.Â  MailSource, L.L.C. v. M.A. Bailey & Assocs., 356 S.C. 363, 368, 588 S.E.2d 635, 638 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The only purpose of an injunction is to preserve the status quo to avoid possible irreparable injury to a party pending litigation.Â  Zabinski v. Bright Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 601, 553 S.E.2d 110, 121 (2001); MailSource, 356 S.C. at 368, 588 S.E.2d at 638.Â  
The trial court found that because Peek was a physician with a private practice, she would suffer irreparable harm while her case against the Hospital was litigated, and that as between Peek and the Hospital, the equities favored Peek.Â  The record supports this conclusion.Â  Peek has lived and practiced anesthesiology in the Spartanburg area for fourteen years.Â  During this time Peek built a patient referral base, which fueled her professional practice.Â  The loss of privileges at the Hospital would lead to the loss of her patient referral base, which would, in turn, lead to the loss of her professional practice.Â  The complete loss of a professional practice can be an irreparable harm.[2]Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court did not abuse its discretion when it found Peek would suffer irreparable harm if the status quo was not maintained.
B.Â Â Â Â Â  Success on the Merits
The Hospital next argues Peek cannot succeed on the merits of the underlying case because the 2004 Agreement is an enforceable exclusive contract.Â  We disagree.
When seeking a preliminary injunction, the plaintiff need not prove an absolute legal right; the plaintiff need only present â€œa fair question to raise as to the existence of such a right.â€Â  Williams v. Jones, 92 S.C. 342, 347, 75 S.E.2d 705, 710 (1912).Â  The determination of whether to grant an injunction should not be based on the merits of the underlying case except insofar as the merits may assist the trial court in determining whether a prima facie showing has been made.Â  MailSource, 356 S.C. at 368, 588 S.E.2d at 638 (citing Transcon. Gas Pipe Line Corp. v. Porter, 252 S.C. 478, 481, 167 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1969)).Â  â€œOnce a prima facie showing has been made entitling the plaintiff to injunctive relief, a temporary injunction will be granted without regard to the ultimate termination of the case on the merits.â€Â  Helsel v. City of North Myrtle Beach, 307 S.C. 29, 32, 413 S.E.2d 824, 826 (1992) (â€œ[I]t would have been improper for the hearing judge who issued the temporary injunction to make a finding upon the facts in such a manner as to affect the merits of the case.â€).Â  
Once the trial court determined Peek made a prima facie showing she was entitled to protection under the Hospital bylaws, the trial court was not required to determine whether the 2004 Agreement was an enforceable exclusive contract because such a finding would affect the merits of the case.Â  Therefore, the trial court did not abuse its discretion in deciding Peek would likely succeed on the merits. 
C.Â Â Â Â Â  Inadequate Remedy at Law
Finally, the Hospital argues Peek had an adequate remedy at law in the form of monetary damages.Â  We disagree.
Again, the purpose of an injunction is the preservation of the status quo.Â  MailSource, 356 S.C. at 368, 588 S.E.2d at 638.Â  â€œA temporary injunction is used to preserve the subject of controversy in the condition which it is at the time of the [o]rder until opportunity is offered for full and deliberate investigation and to preserve the existing status during litigation.â€Â  Id.Â  As explained above, the trial court correctly found that if Peek lost her privileges at the Hospital, her professional practice and, by extension, her career would be lost long before her claims against the Hospital were adjudicated.Â  Furthermore, Peek, who both sides agree is a competent and capable anesthesiologist, would lose expertise if she were not otherwise allowed to exercise her privileges at the hospital while this case is pending, and therefore her future ability to practice anesthesiology would be compromised.Â  While courts do often award monetary damages when a plaintiff can no longer work, such damages are usually the only possible remedy and serve to make the plaintiff as whole as possible under the circumstances.Â  Here, monetary damages are not the only option, and injunctive relief is a better remedy because it would allow Peek to retain both her patient base and her expertise while also retaining her income.Â  Therefore, we find the trial court did not abuse its discretion in finding Peek had an inadequate remedy at law.
CONCLUSION
For the forgoing reasons, the order of the trial court enjoining the Hospital from revoking Peekâ€™s privileges until the merits of her case can be heard is 
AFFIRMED.
 HUFF and WILLIAMS, J.J. concur.

[1]Â  Peekâ€™s competency as a physician is not, and has never been, an issue in this case.Â  
[2]Â  Other appellate courts have upheld injunctive relief to prevent the loss of a business or business goodwill.Â  District of Columbia v. E. Trans-Waste of Md., Inc., 758 A.2d 1, 15 (D.C. 2000) (â€œWhile economic loss does not, in and of itself, constitute irreparable harm, such harm will be found if economic loss threatens the very existence of [plaintiffâ€™s] business.â€); Campbell Inns, Inc. v. Banholzer, Turnure & Co., 527 A.2d 1142, 1146 (Vt. 1987) (â€œThe potential loss of a business satisfies the irreparable harm requirement for the issuance of an injunction.â€); IAC, Ltd. v. Bell Helicopter Textron, Inc., 160 S.W.3d 191, 200 (Tex. App. 2005) (â€œLoss of business goodwill or loss that is not easily calculated in pecuniary terms is sufficient to show irreparable injury for purposes of obtaining a temporary injunction.â€).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Beth Ellen Levine, M.D., Respondent,
v.
Spartanburg Regional Services District, Inc. and Foothills Anesthesia Consultants, P.C.,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4065
Heard November 10, 2005 â€“ Filed December 19, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
H. Spencer King, T. Alexander Evins and Perry Boulier, all of Spartanburg, for Appellants.
A. Camden Lewis, of Columbia and Michael Eugene Spears, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  This is an appeal from an order of the trial court enjoining Spartanburg Regional Services District, Inc. (the Hospital) and Foothills Anesthesia Consultants, P.C. (Foothills) from terminating the privileges of anesthesiologist Beth Ellen Levine until the merits of her case can be adjudicated.Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
Beth Ellen Levine is a licensed physician and board-certified anesthesiologist.Â  Her competency as a physician is not, and has never been, an issue in this case.Â  
On May 1, 2000, the Hospital and Foothills entered into a three-year â€œAnesthesiology Agreementâ€ (2000 Agreement).Â  Under the 2000 Agreement, Foothills agreed to provide the Hospital with anesthesia services performed by licensed and qualified anesthesiologists.Â  Four months later, Foothills and Levine entered into a â€œMedical Service Agreementâ€ (Service Agreement).Â  Under the Service Agreement, Levine agreed to perform anesthesia services for Foothills at the Hospital.Â  The Service Agreement included a three-year term limit as well as an automatic renewal provision.Â  
The renewal provision stated:

At the end of the initial term, this Agreement shall automatically renew for a period of three (3) years unless any party gives written notice to the other party at least ninety (90) days before the end of the renewal term of its intent not to renew the Agreement.Â  [Foothills] agrees that it shall give [Levine] a notice of non-renewal only if the grounds for its decision not to renew this or subsequent Agreements would be grounds for terminating this or subsequent Agreements.Â  If such notice of non-renewal is given and [Levine] elects to exercise the rights available under Section 7(h) of the Agreement prior to the expiration of this or subsequent agreements, the Agreement shall remain in full force and effect at least until the respective rights and obligations of the parties concerning the renewal of the Agreement are determined by final order of the arbitrator.Â  

The 2000 Agreement, by its own terms, ended in May 2003, but the Hospital and Foothills extended it through June.Â  On July 21, 2003, the President of Foothills told Levine the 2000 Agreement had expired.Â  Despite the end of the arrangement between the Hospital and Foothills, Levine continued to perform anesthesia services at the Hospital.Â  
On November 19, 2003, the Hospital Board of Directors (the Board) amended the bylaws to enable the Hospital to enter into an exclusive contract for core anesthesia services.Â  The Board also amended a provision of the bylaws related to the termination of privileges at the Hospital.Â  The amended provision of the bylaws stated:

Where a physician previously has been granted . . . privileges in a Restricted Member Service,[1] and was not, or is no longer, a Contract Physician,[2] the President shall so notify the Board.Â  The Board shall propose the termination of the affected physicianâ€™s privileges . . . .Â  The affected physician shall have the procedural rights set forth in the Medical Staff Bylaws related to revocation of privileges . . . but the only issues for determination in any such proceedings shall be:
  
    
      
        (1) 
         Whether the privileges in question are, in fact, privileges reserved for Restricted Member Services; and
      
      
        (2)  
         Whether the applicant presently is, in fact, a Contract Physician . . . .
      
    
  

(footnotes added).Â  On January 30, 2004, the Hospital and Foothills entered into another three-year agreement (2004 Agreement).Â  
A month later, on February 24, 2004, general counsel for the Hospital notified Levine that if Foothills did not employ her she would lose her privileges at the Hospital.Â  On March 1, 2004, the President of the Hospital informed Levine of the Boardâ€™s decision to terminate her privileges.Â  He informed Levine that she was entitled to procedural rights under the bylaws, â€œbut the only issues for determination in such proceedingsâ€ would be whether Levine was employed by Foothills.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
On March 3, 2004, Levine filed the present action against the Hospital and Foothills for breach of contract, interference with a contractual relationship, violation of due process, and civil conspiracy.Â  Levine also sought a temporary restraining order to prevent the Hospital from terminating her privileges.Â  After a hearing, the trial court granted a temporary injunction against the Hospital and Foothills.Â  Both entities appeal.Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The grant or denial of an injunction by the trial court will not be reversed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Gilley v. Gilley, 327 S.C. 8, 11-12, 488 S.E.2d 310, 312 (1997); MailSource, L.L.C. v. M.A. Bailey & Assocs., 356 S.C. 363, 367, 588 S.E.2d 635, 637-38 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the decision of the trial court is unsupported by the evidence or controlled by an error of law.Â  Ledford v. Pa. Life Ins. Co., 267 S.C. 671, 675, 230 S.E.2d 900, 902 (1976); County of Richland v. Simpkins, 348 S.C. 664, 668, 560 S.E.2d 902, 904 (Ct. App. 2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Hospital and Foothills argue the trial court erred when it enjoined the Hospital from revoking Levineâ€™s privileges.Â  We disagree.Â  
â€œAn injunction is a drastic remedy issued by the court in its discretion to prevent irreparable harm suffered by the plaintiff.â€Â  Scratch Golf Co. v. Dunes W. Residential Golf Props., Inc., 361 S.C. 117, 121, 603 S.E.2d 905, 907 (2004).Â  To obtain an injunction, the plaintiff must allege facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action for injunction and demonstrate the injunction is reasonably necessary to protect the legal rights pending in the litigation.Â  County of Richland v. Simpkins, 348 S.C. 664, 669, 560 S.E.2d 902, 904 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  To establish a cause of action for injunction, the plaintiff must show â€œ(1) it would suffer irreparable harm if the injunction is not granted; (2) it will likely succeed on the merits of the litigation; and (3) there is an inadequate remedy at law.â€Â  Scratch Golf, 361 S.C. at 121, 603 S.E.2d at 908. 
A.Â Â Â Â Â  Irreparable Harm
The Hospital and Foothills argue Levine has not suffered irreparable harm entitling her to injunctive relief because the harm she alleges can be remedied by monetary damages alone.Â  We disagree.Â Â  
The sole purpose of an injunction is to preserve the status quo to avoid potential irreparable injury to the aggrieved party pending litigation.Â  Zabinski v. Bright Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 601, 553 S.E.2d 110, 121 (2001); MailSource, L.L.C. v. M.A. Bailey & Assocs., 356 S.C. 363, 368, 588 S.E.2d 635, 638 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Before granting an injunction, the trial court should balance the equities: the court should look at the particular facts of each case and the equities of each party and determine which side, if any, is more entitled to equitable relief.Â  MailSource, 356 S.C. at 368, 588 S.E.2d at 638.Â  Whether â€œa wrong is irreparable, in the sense that equity may intervene, and whether there is an adequate remedy at law, are questions that are not decided by narrow and artificial rules.â€Â  Kirk v. Clark, 191 S.C. 205, 211, 4 S.E.2d 13, 16 (1939).Â  
The trial court found that Levine, as a physician with a private practice, would suffer irreparable harm if an injunction was not granted.Â  The record supports this conclusion.Â  Levine has built a patient referral base through her work at the Hospital.Â  This referral base would erode and potentially disappear if Levine lost her privileges at the Hospital while the merits of her underlying action against the Hospital and Foothills are adjudicated.Â  Levine would also lose competency in anesthesiology if she were unable to ply her trade as the lawsuit progressed.Â  Such inactivity could lead to the loss of her professional practice and career, which can be an irreparable harm.[3]Â  Therefore, we find the trial court did not abuse its discretion in deciding Levine would suffer irreparable harm without injunctive relief.Â  
B.Â Â Â Â Â  Success on the Merits
The Hospital and Foothills next argue Levine cannot succeed on the merits because the 2004 Agreement is an enforceable exclusive contract and the Service Agreement ended, without renewal, when the 2000 Agreement expired.Â  We disagree.Â  Â Â Â Â Â 
1.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Validity of the 2004 Agreement 
When seeking a preliminary injunction, the plaintiff need not prove an absolute legal right; the plaintiff need only present â€œa fair question to raise as to the existence of such a right.â€Â  Williams v. Jones, 92 S.C. 342, 347, 75 S.E.2d 705, 710 (1912).Â  The determination of whether an injunction is granted should not be based on the merits of the underlying case except insofar as the merits may assist the trial court in determining whether a prima facie showing has been made.Â  MailSource, 356 S.C. at 368, 588 S.E.2d at 638 (citing Transcon. Gas Pipe Line Corp. v. Porter, 252 S.C. 478, 481, 167 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1969)).Â  â€œOnce a prima facie showing has been made entitling the plaintiff to injunctive relief, a temporary injunction will be granted without regard to the ultimate termination of the case on the merits.â€Â  Helsel v. City of North Myrtle Beach, 307 S.C. 29, 32, 413 S.E.2d 824, 826 (1992).Â  
The trial court concluded Levine made a prima facie showing she was entitled to protection under the Hospital bylaws.Â  Once this conclusion was made, the court was not required to determine whether the 2004 Agreement was valid.Â  Accordingly, the trial court did not abuse its discretion in deciding Levine would likely succeed on the merits of the underlying action.Â Â Â Â  
2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Automatic Renewal Provision of the Service Agreement 
The trial court also concluded Levine made a prima facie showing she was entitled to protection under the Service Agreement.Â  The record supports this conclusion as well.Â  Under the Service Agreement, Foothills was required to give Levine notice of its intent not to renew the Service Agreement ninety days before the termination of the Service Agreement.Â  The July 21, 2003 letter from the President of Foothills to Levine does not appear to satisfy this requirement because it was sent within ninety days of the termination of the Service Agreement.Â  Thus, the Service Agreement may have automatically renewed until September 1, 2006.Â  Thus, we find the trial court did not abuse its discretion in determining Levine made a prima facie showing of success on the merits under the Service Agreement. Â Â Â Â Â 
C.Â Â Â Â Â  Inadequate Remedy at Law
Finally, the Hospital and Foothills argue Levine has an adequate remedy at law because she can recover money damages for her injuries.Â  We disagree.Â  
The purpose of an injunction is the preservation of the status quo.Â  MailSource, 356 S.C. at 368, 588 S.E.2d 638.Â  â€œA temporary injunction is used to preserve the subject of controversy in the condition which it is at the time of the [o]rder until opportunity is offered for full and deliberate investigation and to preserve the existing status during litigation.â€Â  Id.Â  As explained above, the trial court decided monetary damages alone would not remedy the harm Levine would sustain if her privileges at the Hospital were terminated.Â  If Levine lost her privileges, her professional practice and, by extension, her career may very well be lost long before her claims against the Hospital and Foothills were finally adjudicated.Â  This point is perhaps best buttressed by a provision of the 2004 Agreement between the Hospital and Foothills that states when privileges are terminated damages will â€œbe difficult, if not impossible, to ascertain, and it is therefore agreed that [the Hospital] and Foothills shall have the right to an injunction or other equitable relief . . . .â€Â  Thus, we find the trial court did not abuse its discretion when it concluded the loss of a professional practice and a career could not be adequately remedied through money damages alone.Â Â Â  
CONCLUSION
For the forgoing reasons, the order of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and WILLIAMS, J.J. concur.

[1]Â  â€œRestricted Member Serviceâ€ includes anesthesiology.Â  
[2]Â  A â€œContract Physicianâ€ is a â€œphysician who is employed by a physician group who is party to an exclusive contract.â€Â  
[3]Â  Other appellate courts have upheld injunctive relief to prevent the loss of a business or business goodwill.Â  District of Columbia v. E. Trans-Waste of Md., Inc., 758 A.2d 1, 15 (D.C. 2000) (â€œWhile economic loss does not, in and of itself, constitute irreparable harm, such harm will be found if economic loss threatens the very existence of [plaintiffâ€™s] business.â€); Campbell Inns, Inc. v. Banholzer, Turnure & Co., 527 A.2d 1142, 1146 (Vt. 1987) (â€œThe potential loss of a business satisfies the irreparable harm requirement for the issuance of an injunction.â€); IAC, Ltd. v. Bell Helicopter Textron, Inc., 160 S.W.3d 191, 200 (Tex. App. 2005) (â€œLoss of business goodwill or loss that is not easily calculated in pecuniary terms is sufficient to show irreparable injury for purposes of obtaining a temporary injunction.â€).
